Partially Personalized Federated Learning:
Breaking the Curse of Data Heterogeneity

Konstantin Mishchenko
Samsung AI Center
Cambridge, UK
&Rustem Islamov
Institut Polytechnique de Paris
Palaiseau, France Eduard Gorbunov
MBZUAI
Abu Dhabi, UAE &Samuel Horv√°th
MBZUAI
Abu Dhabi, UAE
Abstract

We present a partially personalized formulation of Federated Learning (FL) that strikes a balance between the flexibility of personalization and cooperativeness of global training. In our framework, we split the variables into global parameters, which are shared across all clients, and individual local parameters, which are kept private. We prove that under the right split of parameters, it is possible to find global parameters that allow each client to fit their data perfectly, and refer to the obtained problem as overpersonalized. For instance, the shared global parameters can be used to learn good data representations, whereas the personalized layers are fine-tuned for a specific client. Moreover, we present a simple algorithm for the partially personalized formulation that offers significant benefits to all clients. In particular, it breaks the curse of data heterogeneity in several settings, such as training with local steps, asynchronous training, and Byzantine-robust training.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning has emerged as a promising approach to address data privacy concerns and enable distributed learning in various applications, such as healthcare, finance, and mobile devices¬†[29]. In this approach, multiple parties collaboratively train a machine learning model without sharing their raw data with each other, instead, only sharing the model updates with a central server. Despite its potential, Federated Learning faces significant challenges in optimizing the models due to the heterogeneity of the clients‚Äô data, the heterogeneity of the devices involved in training, and the communication constraints¬†[38].

Collaborative Federated Learning aims at uniting a number of private-data holders in order to find together a joint set of parameters x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*} that minimizes their private loss functions:

find¬†x‚àós.t.¬†fm(x‚àó)‚âàargminxfm(x)for all¬†m.(Non-personalized FL)\textrm{find }{\color[rgb]{0,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,.5,.5}x^{*}}\ \textrm{s.t.\ }f_{m}({\color[rgb]{0,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,.5,.5}x^{*}})\approx\arg\min_{x}f_{m}(x)\ \textrm{for all }m.\qquad(\textrm{Non{-}personalized FL})

This formulation, however, is often too restrictive as there might not exist a common model x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*} that fits all participating clients. FL, therefore, often relies on private fine-tuning or personalization to find individual xm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëöx_{m}^{*} for every client mùëöm. This leads to a fully-personalized formulation of FL

find¬†x1‚àó,x2‚àó,‚Ä¶s.t.¬†fm(xm‚àó)‚âàargminxfm(x)for all¬†m.(Personalized FL)\textrm{find }{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}x_{1}^{*}},{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}x_{2}^{*}},\dotsc\ \textrm{s.t.\ }f_{m}({\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}x_{m}^{*}})\approx\arg\min_{x}f_{m}(x)\ \textrm{for all }m.\qquad(\textrm{Personalized FL})

This formulation offers a lot of flexibility at the cost of needing to do more work for every client. Since there is no longer a global model xùë•x trained to perform well on all clients, it is now necessary to find a personalized model for every new client. New clients, therefore, might experience bad performance of the initial model until they obtain enough data to personalize it for their needs.

Thus, having no personalization might be too restrictive, while full personalization can be excessively expensive and inefficient. We strike a balance by splitting the parameters into global and private parts and formulate our problem as

find¬†Œ∏‚àó,w1‚àó,w2‚àó,‚Ä¶s.t.¬†fm(Œ∏‚àó,wm‚àó)‚âàargminŒ∏,wfm(Œ∏,w)for all¬†m.(Partially personalized FL)\textrm{find }{\color[rgb]{0,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,.5,.5}\theta^{*}},{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}w_{1}^{*}},{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}w_{2}^{*}},\dotsc\ \textrm{s.t.\ }f_{m}({\color[rgb]{0,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,.5,.5}\theta^{*}},{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}w_{m}^{*}})\approx\arg\min_{\theta,w}f_{m}(\theta,w)\ \textrm{for all }m.\quad(\textrm{Partially personalized FL})

Above, Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} is the part of the parameters that is shared by all clients, while parameters in wm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m}^{*} are specific to client mùëöm.

1.1 Motivation and formulation

The main interest of our work is to show that the partially personalized formulation gives a significant benefit to all clients as long as there exists a universal Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}. As a motivating example, consider the phenomenon in deep learning where we can train a big network on one task or dataset and fine-tune only its last few layers when working with new source of data. The layers that are not fine-tuned produce so-called representations. The overall objective is then to minimize ‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ¶‚Äã(Œ∏,ùí≥m),wm,ym)‚ÑìŒ¶ùúÉsubscriptùí≥ùëösubscriptùë§ùëösubscriptùë¶ùëö\ell(\Phi(\theta,\mathcal{X}_{m}),w_{m},y_{m}), where ‚Ñì‚Äã(‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ)‚Ñì‚ãÖ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\ell(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot) is a loss function, Œ¶‚Äã(Œ∏,‚ãÖ)Œ¶ùúÉ‚ãÖ\Phi(\theta,\cdot) is the features mapping parameterized by Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, and ùí≥m,ymsubscriptùí≥ùëösubscriptùë¶ùëö\mathcal{X}_{m},y_{m} are the data of the mùëöm-th client. (1)

The values of private wùë§w‚Äôs, on the other hand, are not available to the server to preserve the privacy of the clients. Moreover, to enable stateless-FL applications, where a client might not communicate with the server more than once. To the best of our knowledge, this exact problem has not been studied in optimization literature.

1.2 Our objective

Motivated by the scenario of representation learning, we ask about the potential benefits of partial personalization. In summary, the key aspects of our work are as follows:

  1. 1.

    The problem is partially personalized with global parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\theta (e.g., representations) and local/private parameters wùë§w (e.g., last layers).

  2. 2.

    The data is heterogeneous, but there are sufficiently many parameters in wùë§w to make the solution set of problem¬†(1) is non-empty. Similar to overparameterization in deep learning¬†[4], we call this setting overpersonalized.

  3. 3.

    The clients are stateless by default, i.e., they might not be able to store their private parameters wùë§w, as is often the case in cross-device FL¬†[22].

  4. 4.

    The clients should be able to run arbitrary local optimizers to fine-tune the private part of the model.

  5. 5.

    Our particular interest is in identifying the benefit of local training as well as the positive impact of client cooperation.

It is natural to ask if this objective is reasonable at all. As the next proposition shows, it is always feasible if we allocate sufficiently many parameters in wùë§w.

Proposition 1.

There always exists a split of parameters xùë•x into global and local parameters Œ∏,w1,w2,‚Ä¶ùúÉsubscriptùë§1subscriptùë§2‚Ä¶\theta,w_{1},w_{2},\dotsc such that there exists Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} satisfying Fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)=0subscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùúÉ0F_{m}(\theta^{*})=0 for all mùëöm.

Proof.

The result is trivial: if we set wmsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m} to be all parameters and Œ∏ùúÉ\theta to be any variable such that fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} does not depend on it, then naturally fm‚Äã(Œ∏,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))=minŒ∏‚Ä≤,w‚Å°fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤,w)subscriptùëìùëöùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤ùë§subscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤ùë§f_{m}(\theta,w_{m}^{*}(\theta))=\min_{\theta^{\prime},w}f_{m}(\theta^{\prime},w) and Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)=0subscriptùêπùëöùúÉ0F_{m}(\theta)=0 for all Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. ‚àé

As indicated by Proposition¬†1, splitting the variables to remove the data heterogeneity is always possible. It is nontrival, on the other hand, to find the right split as moving all parameters into wùë§w will eliminate any cooperation between the clients. The interesting case is, therefore, when Œ∏ùúÉ\theta includes sufficiently many parameters that affect fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m}. We leave the question of finding the right split for future work and focus instead on the consequences of having it. In particular, we prove under some mild assumptions, that the partially personalized objective can be cast as a nonlinear equation:

find¬†‚ÄãŒ∏‚àó‚Äãs.t.¬†‚ÄãF‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)=0,find¬†superscriptùúÉs.t.¬†ùêπsuperscriptùúÉ0\textrm{find }\theta^{*}\ \textrm{s.t.\ }F(\theta^{*})=0, (2)

where FùêπF is a nonlinear operator. Moreover, we design algorithms capable of leveraging this property that demonstrate, for the first time, provable benefits of partial personalization.

1.3 Asynchronous training

Heterogeneity in the devices participating in training leads to unbalanced computation time of different clients. The same issue arose in classical distributed optimization, where it was proposed to run asynchronous methods that do not ask the participating devices to synchronize their updates.

While asynchronous methods have been popular in practice in many applications, including Federated Learning¬†[43], their theoretical utility is very limited in the setting of heterogeneous data. This is an expected drawback as when all clients have different functions, clients that participate less will not give us sufficient information, leading to a biased solution. Nevertheless, in this paper, we show that in the context of learning representations, even with heterogeneous data, Asynchronous SGD would converge under arbitrary delays.

1.4 Byzantine attacks in Federated Learning

Many distributed systems face the problem of the presence of Byzantine clients [30, 51, 35]. Standard Federated Learning algorithms are vulnerable to Byzantine attacks even in the case of homogeneous data. For general heterogeneous problems, Byzantine robustness cannot be achieved in general. In this work, we develop a new method for the proposed problem formulation and show its provable robustness to Byzantine attacks, even in the case of heterogeneous data on clients.

1.5 Personalization of representations

In addition, we note that all of our results are immediately applicable in cases where the representations should be personalized, while the last weights can be shared. For instance, in medical applications, different scanners or sensors may have different intensities and contrast, resulting in a feature shift¬†[33]. The labels, however, are shared across hospitals, so we can still train personalized models with shared parameters. In that case, wmsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m} would be responsible for aligning the features, for instance, using batch normalization parameters as done by Li et al.¬†[33], whereas Œ∏ùúÉ\theta would represent the rest of the network.

In cross-device Federated Learning, the features might also change due to use of different phones. As every phone model is equipped with its own version of a photo camera, the layers used to produce the embeddings may need to be readjusted, while the layers deeper in the network can remain the same. Similarly, a robot can be deployed in places with different lighting, so its visual signal may depend on the environment, suggesting that the first layers need to be adjusted. By and large, hardware and environment heterogeneity will demand changes to the part of the network giving us representations, whereas the decision layers can remain intact in such scenarios.

On a final note, personalizing the first layers, which interact with the data, might boost privacy even more than personalization of the last layers. These layers can be used by clients to obfuscate the data source and distribution, while relying on the server to get good universal predictors for generic obfuscated data.

1.6 Related work

Methods for non-personalized FL.

Most methods for Federated Learning stem from the Federated Averaging algorithm (FedAvg) of McMahan et al.¬†[38]. FedAvg itself can be seen as a variant of Local SGD, which received a lot of attention in the optimization literature¬†[36, 50]. The speed of convergence of Local SGD heavily depends on the amount of data heterogeneity, with much slower rates under arbitrary data dissimilarity¬†[27]. Other methods, such as FedProx¬†[32] and Scaffold¬†[25], were proposed to alleviate the issues stemming from data heterogeneity, with provable acceleration if clients can maintain local states¬†[41, 16]. To the best of our knowledge, however, the case of FL with stateless clients and heterogeneous data remains challenging.

Personalization.

FedAvg and other classical algorithms train a single model for all clients. Jiang et al.¬†[21] showed that FedAvg is good at personalization, but this is an implicit property. Various works have proposed alternative methods that run algorithms with explicit personalization, for example using model-agnostic meta-learning¬†[7, 13] or using penalty-based objective¬†[17]. Unlike us, these papers consider full-model personalization and update all parameters.

Partial personalization.

More related to ours, some works split variables into personalized and non-personalized ones. In the context of Meta-Learning with deep networks, Raghu et al.¬†[47] established that only the last few layers needed to be adapted for new tasks. The work of Pillutla et al.¬†[46] is perhaps the closest to ours as they studied optimization properties of partially personalized FL. In particular, they established convergence of algorithms with alternating and simultaneous updates, but unfortunately, their theory does not guarantee any benefit from using multiple gradient steps beyond reducing noise due to extra sampling.

Asynchronous optimization.

Asynchronous SGD has been extensively studied for homogeneous data¬†[53, 1]. Recently, it was shown that Asynchronous SGD converges regardless of the delays in the setting of homogeneous data¬†[40, 28]. Moreover, for heterogeneous data, Asynchronous SGD was to converge to a neighborhood under gradient similarity¬†[40], and to the exact solution under stochastic sampling of clients¬†[28]. However, to the best of our knowledge, Asynchronous SGD is not guaranteed to converge for heterogeneous data without assuming structure in the delays.

Byzantine robustness.

The first approaches to Byzantine-robust distributed learning were concentrated around the replacing of standard averaging in Parallel SGD by some other aggregation rule, which is more robust to the outliers [6, 60, 10, 12, 45]. However, they turned out to be vulnerable to special Byzantine attacks [5, 59] that can be partially explained by the fact that the term ‚Äúrobust aggregation‚Äù was formally introduced later in [23]. In the case of homogeneous data, this discovery led to the development of provably Byzantine-robust distributed methods [23, 14, 15]. In parallel, alternative approaches based on clients‚Äô elimination were developed in [2, 3].

In the arbitrary heterogeneous data case, it is impossible to distinguish regular clients from Byzantine ones. Moreover, even when the heterogeneity (in terms of the gradients‚Äô dissimilarity) is bounded by a constant, there is a lower bounded on the optimization error that can be achieved for a given fraction of Byzantine clients [24], matching/nearly matching upper-bounds were derived in [24, 58, 61, 15]. Nevertheless, in the over-parameterized regime, some methods can still converge to the exact solution (asymptotically) ‚Äì this was shown in [24, 15] for standard Federated Learning formulation. In our work, we continue this line of work by showing that for the proposed problem formulation, one can also achieve provable Byzantine robustness even in the heterogeneous case under similar assumptions about over-parameterization.

Bilevel optimization.

The partially-personalized FL formulation can be seen as a special case of bilevel optimization. Recently, bilevel optimization was also studied in the context of FL¬†[52, 31]. Its main disadvantage is the requirement to differentiate through the inner-level objective, which is typically done by estimating inverse-Jacobian-vector products. Moreover, algorithms for bilevel optimization usually require maintaining the private variable in memory and updating over multiple communication rounds, which is not possible in stateless Federated Learning¬†[22].

The best way to view Assumption¬†1 is as a generalization of convexity and smoothness to nonlinear operators. For instance, if fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} does not depend on wùë§w, then it is enough for it to be convex and LùêøL-smooth¬†[42]. However, our main interest is when parameters wùë§w are personalized, so below, we give a few examples with nontrivial dependence on wùë§w where it provably holds.

Another assumption that we make is regarding overparameterization aspect of the problem. For example, if good data representations exist for all clients, then we can fine-tune wùë§w on each client to perfectly fit the training data. This is formalized below.

Assumption 2.

There exists at least one Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} such that for any client mùëöm, the loss fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó,w)subscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùúÉùë§f_{m}(\theta^{*},w) achieves its minimum with some optimal wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëösuperscriptùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta^{*}), i.e., fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó))=minŒ∏,w‚Å°fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)subscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëösuperscriptùúÉsubscriptùúÉùë§subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§f_{m}(\theta^{*},w_{m}^{*}(\theta^{*}))=\min_{\theta,w}f_{m}(\theta,w).

Notice that Assumption¬†2 requires that Œ∏ùúÉ\theta does not represent personalization to be possible.

Now we give a few examples for which Assumption¬†1 holds. Note that we defer all proofs to the appendix.

Example 1.

Let fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§f_{m}(\theta,w) be given as fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)=œïm‚Äã(Œ∏)+12‚Äã‚ÄñùêÄm‚ÄãŒ∏+ùêÅm‚Äãw‚àíym‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§subscriptitalic-œïùëöùúÉ12superscriptnormsubscriptùêÄùëöùúÉsubscriptùêÅùëöùë§subscriptùë¶ùëö2f_{m}(\theta,w)=\phi_{m}(\theta)+\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{A}_{m}\theta+\mathbf{B}_{m}w-y_{m}\|^{2}, where œïmsubscriptitalic-œïùëö\phi_{m} is any convex Lœïsubscriptùêøitalic-œïL_{\phi}-smooth function. Then, Assumption¬†1 is satisfied with L=2‚Äãmax‚Å°(Lœï,‚ÄñùêÄm‚ä§‚Äã(ùêà‚àíùêÅm‚ÄãùêÅm‚Ä†)‚ÄãùêÄm‚Äñ)ùêø2subscriptùêøitalic-œïnormsuperscriptsubscriptùêÄùëötopùêàsubscriptùêÅùëösuperscriptsubscriptùêÅùëö‚Ä†subscriptùêÄùëöL=2\max(L_{\phi},\|\mathbf{A}_{m}^{\top}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{B}_{m}\mathbf{B}_{m}^{\dagger})\mathbf{A}_{m}\|).

Example¬†1 is a regularized version of the linear regression problem, which has served as a litmus test for verifying if an assumption makes sense. Our assumption is thus validated on this simple example. At the same time, Assumption¬†1 is satisfied for a wider range of functions that include the following example.

Example 2.

Let fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} be twice-differentiable, Œºùúá\mu-strongly convex and LùêøL-smooth in Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. Moreover, assume the cross-term in the Hessian and the Jacobian of wm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m}^{*} to be bounded as ‚Äñ‚àá122fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)‚Äñ‚â§C1normsubscriptsuperscript‚àá212subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§subscriptùê∂1\|\nabla^{2}_{12}f_{m}(\theta,w)\|\leq C_{1}, and ‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äñ‚â§C2normsubscript‚àáùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉsubscriptùê∂2\|\nabla_{\theta}w_{m}^{*}(\theta)\|\leq C_{2} with C1‚ÄãC2‚â§Œº2subscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂2ùúá2C_{1}C_{2}\leq\frac{\mu}{2}. Then, FmsubscriptùêπùëöF_{m} is cocoercive and Œº2ùúá2\frac{\mu}{2}-strongly monotone.

Example¬†2 provides a general recipe for an objective to satisfy Assumption¬†1. It is somewhat restrictive as it requires smoothness of both fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} and wm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m}^{*}, but these assumption are, in fact, natural. Smoothness of fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} is commonly assumed to make minimization of fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} possible¬†[42]. The assumption on smoothness of wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) is directly related to the assumptions employed in the theory of minmax optimization, see, for example, [44]. Moreover, it is possible to ensure wm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m}^{*} is Lipschitz by adding Œª2‚Äã‚Äñw‚Äñ2ùúÜ2superscriptnormùë§2\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w\|^{2} to fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m}, see Lemma B.1 in [44].

Let us also add a small generalization of Example¬†1 to the case of the composition of a smooth nonlinear functions and linear transformations.

Example 3.

Let fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§f_{m}(\theta,w) be given as fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)=œïm‚Äã(Œ∏)+œàm‚Äã(ùêÄm‚ÄãŒ∏+ùêÅm‚Äãw‚àíym)subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§subscriptitalic-œïùëöùúÉsubscriptùúìùëösubscriptùêÄùëöùúÉsubscriptùêÅùëöùë§subscriptùë¶ùëöf_{m}(\theta,w)=\phi_{m}(\theta)+\psi_{m}(\mathbf{A}_{m}\theta+\mathbf{B}_{m}w-y_{m}), where œàmsubscriptùúìùëö\psi_{m} and œïmsubscriptitalic-œïùëö\phi_{m} are any convex and L2ùêø2\frac{L}{2}-smooth functions. Then, Assumption¬†1 is satisfied.

This example is particularly interesting through the perspective of parameter-efficient fine-tuning. Methods such as Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) [20], fine-tune linear layers by adding low-rank perturbations. Specifically, the linear layer is split into two parts, similarly to how we compute ùêÄm‚ÄãŒ∏+ùêÅm‚ÄãwsubscriptùêÄùëöùúÉsubscriptùêÅùëöùë§\mathbf{A}_{m}\theta+\mathbf{B}_{m}w in Example¬†3. Note that ùêÅmsubscriptùêÅùëö\mathbf{B}_{m} can have a rank much smaller than ùêÄmsubscriptùêÄùëö\mathbf{A}_{m}.

2.1 An algorithm for the proposed formulation

Having defined a formulation of partial personalization, it is very easy to derive an algorithm that will solve it. Under our assumptions, it is enough to update the global parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\theta using the standard gradient-descent update. However, in practice, we need to compute wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) using local gradients updates. This gives us a double-loop method, which we present in Algorithm¬†1.

We present the convergence theory for Algorithm¬†1 and its variants in several cases. First of all, let us understand how its idealistic version, which computes wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) exactly, would converge under our assumptions.

Theorem 1.

Let Assumptions¬†1-2 hold and assume that we use exact updates, wmr,œÑ=arg‚Å°minw‚Å°fm‚Äã(Œ∏r,w)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùëüùúèsubscriptùë§subscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùúÉùëüùë§w_{m}^{r,\tau}=\arg\min_{w}f_{m}(\theta^{r},w). If we choose Œ≥Œ∏‚â§1LsubscriptùõæùúÉ1ùêø\gamma_{\theta}\leq\frac{1}{L}, then

minr<R‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñF‚Äã(Œ∏r)‚Äñ2]‚â§L‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏0‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2Œ≥Œ∏‚ÄãR,subscriptùëüùëÖùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùêπsuperscriptùúÉùëü2ùêøsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùúÉ0superscriptùúÉ2subscriptùõæùúÉùëÖ\min_{r<R}\mathbb{E}\left[\|F(\theta^{r})\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{L\|\theta^{0}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{\gamma_{\theta}R},

where Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} is any vector such that F‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)=0ùêπsuperscriptùúÉ0F(\theta^{*})=0.

If we compare this to the standard bounds on convergence of gradient descent, we can see that there is no slowdown. In this sense, personalization completely removes the issues of data heterogeneity, which usually causes FL method to converge slower¬†[26]. In more practical scenarios, Algorithm¬†1 will compute wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) inexactly, which will affect the convergence. The next theorem outlines what happens in that case.

Theorem 2 (Informal).

Let Assumptions¬†1-2 hold and fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} be smooth and strongly convex in wùë§w. If œÑùúè\tau is large enough, then

minr<R‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñF‚Äã(Œ∏r)‚Äñ2]‚â§4‚ÄãL‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏0‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2Œ≥Œ∏‚ÄãR.subscriptùëüùëÖùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùêπsuperscriptùúÉùëü24ùêøsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùúÉ0superscriptùúÉ2subscriptùõæùúÉùëÖ\min\limits_{r<R}\mathbb{E}\left[\|F(\theta^{r})\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{4L\|\theta^{0}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{\gamma_{\theta}R}.

We formulate Theorem¬†2 more rigorously in the supplementary material, see Theorem¬†6. The main message, however, remains the same. Moreover, we can see that the local updates are important, which is in stark contrast to the theory in [46], where having more local updates does not improve convergence.

2.2 Breaking the curse in other settings

Asynchronous communications.

We consider Algorithm¬†3, asynchronous variant of Algorithm¬†1. For this method, whenever one of the clients finishes local computations, the server immediately uses client‚Äôs update to perform a step, and then that client begins local work starting from newly updated global parameters. The following result holds in this setting.

Theorem 3 (Informal).

Let Assumptions¬†1-2 hold and assume that we use exact updates. Assume the delays and the number of active clients are bounded. Then

minr<R‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñF‚Äã(Œ∏r)‚Äñ2]‚â§2‚ÄãL‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏^0‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2Œ≥Œ∏‚ÄãR,subscriptùëüùëÖùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùêπsuperscriptùúÉùëü22ùêøsuperscriptnormsuperscript^ùúÉ0superscriptùúÉ2subscriptùõæùúÉùëÖ\min\limits_{r<R}\mathbb{E}\left[\|F(\theta^{r})\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{2L\|\hat{\theta}^{0}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{\gamma_{\theta}R},

where Œ∏^0superscript^ùúÉ0\hat{\theta}^{0} is defined in¬†(15).

We highlight the fact that the proposed problem formulation allows for Algorithm¬†1 to converge in arbitrarily heterogeneous regime. The detailed formulation and proof of this result can be found in the supplementary material, see Theorem¬†7.

Byzantine-robust learning.

To achieve Byzantine robustness, our method needs a small but very important modification: in line¬†8, instead of averaging, we apply agnostic (Œ¥,c)ùõøùëê(\delta,c)-robust aggregation (see Definition¬†2 in the appendix): Œ∏r+1=Œ∏r‚àíŒ≥Œ∏‚ÄãARAgg‚Äã(Œî1r,Œî2r,‚Ä¶,ŒîMr)superscriptùúÉùëü1superscriptùúÉùëüsubscriptùõæùúÉARAggsuperscriptsubscriptŒî1ùëüsuperscriptsubscriptŒî2ùëü‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptŒîùëÄùëü\theta^{r+1}=\theta^{r}-\gamma_{\theta}\texttt{ARAgg}(\Delta_{1}^{r},\Delta_{2}^{r},\ldots,\Delta_{M}^{r}), where {1,‚Ä¶,M}1‚Ä¶ùëÄ\{1,\ldots,M\} is the set of all clients, B‚â§Œ¥‚ÄãMùêµùõøùëÄB\leq\delta M of them are Byzantines and Œ¥<1/2ùõø12\delta<\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}} (see the detailed setup in Appendix¬†D). For this version of the method, we derive the following result.

Theorem 4 (Informal).

Let operators FmsubscriptùêπùëöF_{m} be ‚Ñìmsubscript‚Ñìùëö\ell_{m}-cocoercive, FùêπF be strongly monotone, and good clients compute stochastic estimates satisfying ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgm‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äñ2]‚â§œÅin‚Äã‚ÄñFm‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äñ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëöùúÉ2subscriptùúåinsuperscriptnormsubscriptùêπùëöùúÉ2\mathbb{E}[\|g_{m}(\theta)\|^{2}]\leq\rho_{\text{in}}\|F_{m}(\theta)\|^{2}. If Œ¥ùõø\delta is small enough, then for Byzantine-robust version of Algorithm¬†1 we have

ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñŒ∏R‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2]‚â§(1‚àíŒ≥Œ∏‚ÄãŒº2)R‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏0‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2.ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùúÉùëÖsuperscriptùúÉ2superscript1subscriptùõæùúÉùúá2ùëÖsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùúÉ0superscriptùúÉ2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\theta^{R}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}\right]\leq\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{\theta}\mu}{2}\right)^{R}\|\theta^{0}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}.

We emphasize that for arbitrary heterogeneous problems, it is impossible to tolerate even one Byzantine client. In contrast, Theorem¬†4 implies that for the considered problem formulation, the proposed algorithm converges linearly to the exact solution (asymptotically) even when data on clients is heterogeneous and a small amount of Byzantines takes part in the training. The complete formulation of the above result is deferred to the supplementary material, see Theorem¬†8.

2.3 Benefit of cooperation

As discussed in the introduction, we could have chosen to fit the local data on each client individually. However, the drawback of such approach is that the clients will not benefit from cooperative training. Here, we show that having partial personalization allows to find parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that are useful for all clients. This implies that in expectation, a new client mùëöm that receives Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} as initialization will have a better value of post-training risk fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))subscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉf_{m}(\theta^{*},w_{m}^{*}(\theta)).

For simplicity, we showcase the benefit on the function from Example¬†1 with regularizers œïm‚Äã(Œ∏)‚â°0subscriptitalic-œïùëöùúÉ0\phi_{m}(\theta)\equiv 0. We have the following result.

Theorem 5.

Let fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)=12‚Äã‚ÄñùêÄm‚ÄãŒ∏+ùêÅm‚Äãw‚àíym‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§12superscriptnormsubscriptùêÄùëöùúÉsubscriptùêÅùëöùë§subscriptùë¶ùëö2f_{m}(\theta,w)=\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{A}_{m}\theta+\mathbf{B}_{m}w-y_{m}\|^{2} and assume we found Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} such that ùîºm‚Äã[Fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)]=0subscriptùîºùëödelimited-[]subscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùúÉ0\mathbb{E}_{m}[F_{m}(\theta^{*})]=0. Then, Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} minimizes the expected risk ùîºm‚Äã[fm‚Äã(Œ∏,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))]subscriptùîºùëödelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëöùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉ\mathbb{E}_{m}[f_{m}(\theta,w_{m}^{*}(\theta))].

The key observation of Theorem¬†5 is that finding the solution to ùîº‚Äã[Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)]=0ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùêπùëöùúÉ0\mathbb{E}\left[F_{m}(\theta)\right]=0 is equivalent to minimizing ùîº‚Äã[fm‚Äã(Œ∏,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëöùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉ\mathbb{E}\left[f_{m}(\theta,w_{m}^{*}(\theta))\right]. This is surprising because the gradient of the latter is not equal to ùîº‚Äã[Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùêπùëöùúÉ\mathbb{E}\left[F_{m}(\theta)\right]. Nevertheless, the obtained Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} turns out to be optimal for solving a more challenging bilevel optimization problem.

When we combine the result of Theorem¬†5 with Assumption¬†2, we get

(Œ∏‚àó,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))=argminŒ∏,w‚Å°fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)for all¬†‚Äãm.superscriptùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉsubscriptargminùúÉùë§subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§for all¬†ùëö(\theta^{*},w_{m}^{*}(\theta))=\operatorname{argmin}_{\theta,w}f_{m}(\theta,w)\qquad\text{for all }m.

This means that the combined partially personalized model Œ∏‚àó,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)superscriptùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëösuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*},w_{m}^{*}(\theta^{*}) fits the data of client mùëöm perfectly. When the model is deployed using the found Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}, all new client benefit from having a part of the model pretrained optimally for them. This reduces the computation load, especially if Œ∏ùúÉ\theta is a big part of the model.

2.4 How to split the parameters

The derived theory gives us the following insights:

  1. 1.

    To break the curse of data heterogeneity, the personalized part of the model wùë§w must be sufficiently large. Then, Assumption¬†2 is satisfied and the training will be easier.

  2. 2.

    If the previous condition is satisfied, Theorem¬†5 suggests that every client will be able to fit the data perfectly by fine-tuning only wùë§w. Thus, the smaller personalized part wùë§w is, the easier will be its fine-tuning.

Therefore, the balance between Œ∏ùúÉ\theta and wùë§w when splitting the parameters is crucial. In some cases, it is known that fine-tuning just the batch normalization layers can be sufficient¬†[33]. Our theory suggests that the key quantity to measure the quality of the split is ‚ÄñFm‚Äã(Œ∏)‚ÄñnormsubscriptùêπùëöùúÉ\|F_{m}(\theta)\|, which we can compute in practice. If it is too close to 0, Œ∏ùúÉ\theta will not be updated, so one should consider decreasing the number of personalized parameters. It seems less obvious how to detect that we should personalize more parameters. This question deserves a solid study, so we leave a further exploration of optimal parameter splits for future work.

3 Experiments

The detailed description of all experimental setups is deferred to the Appendix¬†E.

3.1 The more local work, the better the convergence

In our first experiment, we study the convergence of Algorithm¬†1 with inexact gradient computation. We test it on the problem from Example¬†1, namely:

œàm‚Äã(Œ∏)=12‚Äã‚Äñùêám‚ÄãŒ∏‚àíbm‚Äñ2,fm‚Äã(Œ∏,w)=œàm‚Äã(Œ∏)+12‚Äã‚ÄñùêÄm‚ÄãŒ∏+ùêÅm‚Äãw‚àíym‚Äñ2,formulae-sequencesubscriptùúìùëöùúÉ12superscriptnormsubscriptùêáùëöùúÉsubscriptùëèùëö2subscriptùëìùëöùúÉùë§subscriptùúìùëöùúÉ12superscriptnormsubscriptùêÄùëöùúÉsubscriptùêÅùëöùë§subscriptùë¶ùëö2\psi_{m}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{H}_{m}\theta-b_{m}\|^{2},\quad f_{m}(\theta,w)=\psi_{m}(\theta)+\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{A}_{m}\theta+\mathbf{B}_{m}w-y_{m}\|^{2},

where ùêám,ùêÄm‚àà‚Ñùn√ódŒ∏,ùêÅm‚àà‚Ñùn√ódw,bm,ym‚àà‚Ñùnformulae-sequencesubscriptùêáùëösubscriptùêÄùëösuperscript‚ÑùùëõsubscriptùëëùúÉformulae-sequencesubscriptùêÅùëösuperscript‚Ñùùëõsubscriptùëëùë§subscriptùëèùëösubscriptùë¶ùëösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbf{H}_{m},\mathbf{A}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{\theta}},\mathbf{B}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{w}},b_{m},y_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} with n=10000ùëõ10000n=10000, dŒ∏=100,dw=50.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëëùúÉ100subscriptùëëùë§50d_{\theta}=100,d_{w}=50. The number of clients is 32.3232. All matrices are generated from uniform distribution on [0,1]01[0,1], and then divided by the second dimension (i.e., dŒ∏subscriptùëëùúÉd_{\theta} for ùêám,ùêÄmsubscriptùêáùëösubscriptùêÄùëö\mathbf{H}_{m},\mathbf{A}_{m} and dwsubscriptùëëùë§d_{w} for ùêÅmsubscriptùêÅùëö\mathbf{B}_{m}).

We use SciPy‚Äôs [56] implementation of Conjugate Gradient (CG) method to solve local subproblem in wùë§w and vary the number of inner steps œÑùúè\tau of CG (see Figure¬†1, (a)). The convergence with a small number of local steps œÑ=10ùúè10\tau=10 is already sufficient to achieve an error as small as 10‚àí4superscript10410^{-4}. Moreover, Algorithm¬†1 converges to the exact solution for œÑ‚àà{30,40}ùúè3040\tau\in\{30,40\}, i.e., without finding the precise solution of the local subproblem. This experiment shows that the convergence of FFGG indeed improves with an increasing amount of local work, and the method is overall practical.

3.2 Comparison against other methods

Next, we compare FFGG combined with Algorithm¬†2 as a fine-tuner against non-personalized methods such as Scaffold [25] and Local GD, and fully personalized method L2GD [17]. For Scaffold we set outer and inner stepsizes to be equal to 0.50.50.5 and 1Lf‚ÄãœÑ1subscriptùêøùëìùúè\frac{1}{L_{f}\tau} correspondingly, where LfsubscriptùêøùëìL_{f} is a smoothness constant of fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m}. For Local GD the stepsize is equal to 1Lf‚ÄãœÑ1subscriptùêøùëìùúè\frac{1}{L_{f}\tau}. Finally, for L2GD we choose Œª=0.1ùúÜ0.1\lambda=0.1 and stepsize to be equal to (2‚ÄãM)‚àí1‚Äãmax‚Å°{L‚Äã(1‚àíp)‚àí1,Œª‚Äãp‚àí1}superscript2ùëÄ1ùêøsuperscript1ùëù1ùúÜsuperscriptùëù1(2M)^{-1}\max\left\{L(1-p)^{-1},\lambda p^{-1}\right\}, where p=œÑ‚àí1ùëùsuperscriptùúè1p=\tau^{-1} (we make such choice for pùëùp to make the number of local steps to be close to œÑùúè\tau in expectation).

We test the convergence of the methods changing the number of local steps œÑ‚àà{100,200,500}ùúè100200500\tau\in\{100,200,500\}. Figure¬†1 (b-d) shows that FFGG outperforms other baselines in all cases. We also highlight that FFGG‚Äôs convergence improves when we increase the number of local steps as it is predicted by theory.

3.3 Comparison on real-world datasets

Finally, we evaluate our method on real-world federated datasets, namely FEMNIST (character recognition), GLDv2 (Visual Landmark Recognition), and StackOverflow (next word prediction), and show that partial participation leads to a non-trivial performance boost when compared to non-personalized FedAvg. We follow the same setup as [46]. All the experimental details and hyperparameter selections are provided in the appendix. As a partial personalization, we consider three partitioning schemes:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Input layer personalization: This architectural design customizes the input layer to learn personalized representations, whereas the remaining part of the model is common to all clients. For predicting the next word, the initial transformer layer is personalized instead of the embedding layer.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Output layer personalization: This design learns a common representation but customizes the prediction layer. In a transformer model, we adapt the final transformer layer instead of the output layer for personalization.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Adapter personalization: Every client uses a personalized low-rank adapter to fine-tune the global model.

We also introduce an algorithmic extension to Algorithm¬†1 to incorporate local steps with respect to global parameters into the training loop. After receiving a global model from the server, clients randomly initialize personalized parameters and perform one local epoch with respect to these parameters to approximate wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta). Following this step, we alternate between stochastic gradient steps with respect to global and local parameters. We only initialize wmsubscriptùë§ùëöw_{m} at the beginning of local training. This approach allows us to approximate wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) with a single gradient step after initial fine-tuning. The pseudocode for this algorithm is provided in Algorithm¬†4. Our results are presented in Table¬†1. The displayed values represent averages over three independent seeds. It is worth noting that for both datasets, FFGG leads to an improvement of at least one percent in final test accuracy. We also observe that Adapter is a particularly useful technique for partially personalizing local models. The largest improvement, exceeding 13%, is observed for FFFG (Adapter) on the GLDv2 dataset. In this particular case, the final train accuracy for all clients is 100%, which aligns well with our theory as it implies that Fm‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)=0subscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùúÉ0F_{m}({\color[rgb]{0,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,.5,.5}\theta^{*}})=0.

4 Conclusion

We proposed a formulation of partial personalization that yields provable benefits in Federated Learning. We proved that the problem can always be made overpersonalized and the data heterogeneity slowdown can be completely eradicated. We also illustrated this by showing that, in contrast to standard FL, asynchronous training with partial personalization converges precisely, and partial personalization can be made Byzantine-robust. Our theory also suggests algorithmic changes to how the training should be performed and allows for generic local solvers. Compared to the work of Pillutla et al.¬†[46], our methods are stateless, and our theory does not require making stepsizes smaller than ùí™‚Äã(1/œÑ)ùí™1ùúè\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{1}}{{\tau}}\right), where œÑùúè\tau is the number of local steps. Finally, our assumptions are satisfied for several natural classes of functions, highlighting that our formulation is quite general.

There are several open questions that can be of interest to make personalization more practical. First of all, a direction that seems important to us is how we can find optimal splits between Œ∏ùúÉ\theta and wùë§w to achieve both the speed up of removed data heterogeneity and make sure that clients benefit from cooperation. Secondly, parameter-efficient fine-tuning might bring even more speed ups. Lastly, while the statistical effect of cooperation was left out of consideration in our work, it can bring new insights and deserves some attention.

A.3 Proof of cocoercivity for Example¬†3

Example¬†3 is the hardest to study. First, we state and prove the following standard result.

Proposition 2.

Let œÜ1,œÜ2subscriptùúë1subscriptùúë2\varphi_{1},\varphi_{2} be LùêøL-smooth convex functions. Then œÜ=œÜ1+œÜ2ùúësubscriptùúë1subscriptùúë2\varphi=\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2} is (2‚ÄãL)2ùêø(2L)-cocoercive.

‚ü®‚àáœÜ‚Äã(Œ∏1)‚àí‚àáœÜ‚Äã(Œ∏2),Œ∏1‚àíŒ∏2‚ü©‚àáùúësubscriptùúÉ1‚àáùúësubscriptùúÉ2subscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ2\displaystyle\langle\nabla\varphi(\theta_{1})-\nabla\varphi(\theta_{2}),\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\rangle =‚ü®‚àáœÜ1‚Äã(Œ∏1)‚àí‚àáœÜ1‚Äã(Œ∏2),Œ∏1‚àíŒ∏2‚ü©+‚ü®‚àáœÜ2‚Äã(Œ∏1)‚àí‚àáœÜ2‚Äã(Œ∏2),Œ∏1‚àíŒ∏2‚ü©absent‚àásubscriptùúë1subscriptùúÉ1‚àásubscriptùúë1subscriptùúÉ2subscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ2‚àásubscriptùúë2subscriptùúÉ1‚àásubscriptùúë2subscriptùúÉ2subscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ2\displaystyle=\langle\nabla\varphi_{1}(\theta_{1})-\nabla\varphi_{1}(\theta_{2}),\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\rangle+\langle\nabla\varphi_{2}(\theta_{1})-\nabla\varphi_{2}(\theta_{2}),\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\rangle

A.4 Proof of Theorem¬†1

Appendix C Asynchronous method

We formulate and prove the convergence of Algorithm¬†3 (which is the asynchronous version of Algorithm¬†1) with exact computations only. i.e., in line¬†7 the subproblem is solved exactly. However, the convergence of inexact version can be derived in similar way as for Algorithm¬†1 in Appendix¬†B. As defined in Algorithm¬†3, we denote the client that finishes the computation at iteration rùëür as jrsubscriptùëóùëüj_{r} and the newly sampled client as mrsubscriptùëöùëüm_{r}.

To prove the convergence, we define prev‚Å°(m,r)=defmax‚Å°{j<r:mj=m}superscriptdefprevùëöùëü:ùëóùëüsubscriptùëöùëóùëö\operatorname{prev}(m,r)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\max\{j<r\,:\,m_{j}=m\} ‚Äî the last iteration before iteration rùëür when the update from client mùëöm was applied. Our analysis is based on the virtual iterates, also known as perturbed iterates, that were introduced by Mania et al.¬†[37]. In particular, we consider the sequence defined recursively as

Œ∏^r+1=Œ∏^r‚àíŒ≥Œ∏‚ÄãFmr‚Äã(Œ∏r).superscript^ùúÉùëü1superscript^ùúÉùëüsubscriptùõæùúÉsubscriptùêπsubscriptùëöùëüsuperscriptùúÉùëü\hat{\theta}^{r+1}=\hat{\theta}^{r}-\gamma_{\theta}F_{m_{r}}(\theta^{r}). (14)

We also use initialization

since all initially sampled clients will compute their gradients using Œ∏0superscriptùúÉ0\theta^{0}. The set of active clients Crsuperscriptùê∂ùëüC^{r} initialized with C0superscriptùê∂0C^{0} is updated according to Cr+1={mr}‚à™(Cr‚àñ{jr})superscriptùê∂ùëü1subscriptùëöùëüsuperscriptùê∂ùëüsubscriptùëóùëüC^{r+1}=\{m_{r}\}\cup(C^{r}\setminus\{j_{r}\}). We assume that Crsuperscriptùê∂ùëüC^{r} is always bounded, which is satisfied, for instance, when the total number of clients is finite. We assume that delays are bounded.

Assumption 5.

There exists a constant œÑmaxsubscriptùúè\tau_{\max} such that for any client mùëöm at iteration rùëür the following inequality holds: |prev‚Å°(m,r)‚àír|‚â§œÑmax,prevùëöùëüùëüsubscriptùúè|\operatorname{prev}(m,r)-r|\leq\tau_{\max}, i.e., all the delays are bounded by œÑmax.subscriptùúè\tau_{\max}.

Remark 3.

We highlight the fact that if we use the stepsize Œ≥Œ∏=12‚ÄãL‚Äã2‚ÄãM‚ÄãœÑmax,subscriptùõæùúÉ12ùêø2ùëÄsubscriptùúè\gamma_{\theta}=\frac{1}{2L\sqrt{2M\tau_{\max}}}, then the convergence is

minr<R‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñF‚Äã(Œ∏r)‚Äñ2]‚â§4‚ÄãL2‚Äã2‚ÄãM‚ÄãœÑmax‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏^0‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚Äñ2R.subscriptùëüùëÖùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùêπsuperscriptùúÉùëü24superscriptùêø22ùëÄsubscriptùúèsuperscriptnormsuperscript^ùúÉ0superscriptùúÉ2ùëÖ\min\limits_{r<R}\mathbb{E}\left[\|F(\theta^{r})\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{4L^{2}\sqrt{2M\tau_{\max}}\|\hat{\theta}^{0}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{R}.

We observe a square root dependency on œÑmaxsubscriptùúè\tau_{\max}. The same result has been recently derived in homogeneous setting [28] for vanilla Asynchronous SGD.

Appendix D Byzantine-robust version

Preliminaries.

We assume that among MùëÄM clients participating in the training, there is a subset of clients ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B} called Byzantines, i.e., clients that can (intentionally or not) deviate from the prescribed algorithm and are omniscient (i.e., they know the updates of other clients and aggregation rule applied by the server). More precisely, we assume that [M]=ùí¢‚äî‚Ñ¨delimited-[]ùëÄsquare-unionùí¢‚Ñ¨[M]=\mathcal{G}\sqcup\mathcal{B}, where ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} denotes the set of regular clients, |ùí¢|=defGsuperscriptdefùí¢ùê∫|\mathcal{G}|\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}G, |‚Ñ¨|=defB‚â§Œ¥‚ÄãMsuperscriptdef‚Ñ¨ùêµùõøùëÄ|\mathcal{B}|\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}B\leq\delta M, where Œ¥<1/2ùõø12\delta<\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}. The goal is to solve an instance of (2) with

F‚Äã(Œ∏)=1G‚Äã‚àëm‚ààùí¢Fm‚Äã(Œ∏),ùêπùúÉ1ùê∫subscriptùëöùí¢subscriptùêπùëöùúÉF(\theta)=\frac{1}{G}\sum\limits_{m\in\mathcal{G}}F_{m}(\theta), (17)

where operators {Fm}m‚ààùí¢subscriptsubscriptùêπùëöùëöùí¢\{F_{m}\}_{m\in\mathcal{G}} are defined as Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)=‚àá1fm‚Äã(Œ∏,wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏))subscriptùêπùëöùúÉsubscript‚àá1subscriptùëìùëöùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉF_{m}(\theta)=\nabla_{1}f_{m}(\theta,w_{m}^{*}(\theta)).

Since the standard averaging is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks, we use robust aggregation rules in the sense of the following definition.

Definition 2 ((Œ¥,c)ùõøùëê(\delta,c)-robust aggregator [23, 24, 15]).

Let random vectors {x1,‚Ä¶,xM}subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÄ\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{M}\} are such that there exists a subset ùí¢‚äÜ[M]ùí¢delimited-[]ùëÄ\mathcal{G}\subseteq[M] such that |ùí¢|=G‚â•(1‚àíŒ¥)‚Äãnùí¢ùê∫1ùõøùëõ|\mathcal{G}|=G\geq(1-\delta)n where Œ¥<1/2ùõø12\delta<\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}} and for some œÉ‚â•0ùúé0\sigma\geq 0 the following inequality holds: 1G‚Äã(G‚àí1)‚Äã‚àëm,n‚ààùí¢ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñxm‚àíxn‚Äñ2]‚â§œÉ21ùê∫ùê∫1subscriptùëöùëõùí¢ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëõ2superscriptùúé2\tfrac{1}{G(G-1)}\sum_{m,n\in\mathcal{G}}\mathbb{E}[\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2} where the expectation is taken w.r.t.¬†the randomness of {xm}m‚ààùí¢subscriptsubscriptùë•ùëöùëöùí¢\{x_{m}\}_{m\in\mathcal{G}}. Then, vector x^^ùë•\widehat{x} is called (Œ¥,c)ùõøùëê(\delta,c)-Robust Aggregator ((Œ¥,c)‚àíRAggùõøùëêRAgg(\delta,c)-\texttt{RAgg}) for some c>0ùëê0c>0 and denoted as x^=RAgg‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xM)^ùë•RAggsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÄ\widehat{x}=\texttt{RAgg}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{M}) if the following condition holds:

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñx^‚àíx¬Ø‚Äñ2]‚â§c‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãœÉ2,ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm^ùë•¬Øùë•2ùëêùõøsuperscriptùúé2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\widehat{x}-\overline{x}\|^{2}\right]\leq c\delta\sigma^{2}, (18)

where x¬Ø=1G‚Äã‚àëm‚ààùí¢xi¬Øùë•1ùê∫subscriptùëöùí¢subscriptùë•ùëñ\overline{x}=\tfrac{1}{G}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{G}}x_{i}. If, in addition, the computation of x^^ùë•\widehat{x} is independent of œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}, x^^ùë•\widehat{x} is called (Œ¥,c)ùõøùëê(\delta,c)-Agnostic Robust Aggregator ((Œ¥,c)‚àíARAggùõøùëêARAgg(\delta,c)-\texttt{ARAgg}) and denoted as x^=ARAgg‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xM)^ùë•ARAggsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÄ\widehat{x}=\texttt{ARAgg}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{M}).

This definition is tight in a certain sense (see the details in [23]) and is not satisfied for such defenses as Krum [6], geometric median [45], and coordinate-wise median [8] that are known to be insufficient to ensure Byzantine-robustness [5, 59]. For the examples of aggregators satisfying Definition¬†2 we refer to [15].

We also make an additional assumption related to the over-parameterization.

Assumption 6.

We assume that any regular client m‚ààùí¢ùëöùí¢m\in\mathcal{G} can compute an unbiased estimate gm‚Äã(Œ∏)subscriptùëîùëöùúÉg_{m}(\theta) of Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)subscriptùêπùëöùúÉF_{m}(\theta), i.e., ùîº‚Äã[gm‚Äã(Œ∏)]=Fm‚Äã(Œ∏)ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëîùëöùúÉsubscriptùêπùëöùúÉ\mathbb{E}[g_{m}(\theta)]=F_{m}(\theta), and for any Œ∏‚àà‚ÑùdùúÉsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

Standard strong monotonicity, i.e., ‚ü®Fm‚Äã(Œ∏1)‚àíFm‚Äã(Œ∏2),Œ∏1‚àíŒ∏2‚ü©‚â•Œº‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏1‚àíŒ∏2‚Äñ2subscriptùêπùëösubscriptùúÉ1subscriptùêπùëösubscriptùúÉ2subscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ2ùúásuperscriptnormsubscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ22\langle F_{m}(\theta_{1})-F_{m}(\theta_{2}),\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\rangle\geq\mu\|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\|^{2} for any Œ∏1,Œ∏2‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúÉ2superscript‚Ñùùëë\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, implies condition from (21) [39, 49, 34] but the opposite implication is not always true. Moreover, as it is shown in [34], an operator can be non-monotone but quasi-strongly monotone.

The derived result establishes linear convergence to the exact solution (asymptotically, in expectation) with the possible presence of Byzantine clients. Up to numerical constants and the differences between definitions of LùêøL and Œºùúá\mu in our work and in [24, 15], we get the same worst-case upper-bound for Œ¥ùõø\delta.

However, when ‚Ñìsim‚â™Lmuch-less-thansubscript‚Ñìsimùêø\ell_{\text{sim}}\ll L, our condition on Œ¥ùõø\delta can be very mild. For example, when the data on workers is similar to a certain extent, then ‚Ñìsimsubscript‚Ñìsim\ell_{\text{sim}} can be of the order of Œºùúá\mu or even smaller. In this case, our condition on Œ¥ùõø\delta can become void, and the upper bound for Œ¥ùõø\delta will be determined by the type of aggregation rule (see the examples in [24]).

Appendix E Experiments

E.1 Expertimental details for real-world datasets

As mentioned in the main part, we adhere to the experimental arrangement outlined in Pillutla et al. (2022) for consistency [46]. To provide comprehensive information, we present the setup below.

Our experiments are conducted using two datasets encompassing two modalities, specifically images, and text. These datasets feature a natural division of data that is non-i.i.d., mirroring the heterogeneity of data encountered in real-world Federated Learning scenarios. We provide a detailed account of the experimental setup and hyperparameters employed. We base our implementation on the publicly available code provided by Pillutla et al. (2022) 111https://github.com/facebookresearch/FL_partial_personalization.

E.2 Datasets, tasks and models

We explore two tasks inspired by real-world applications of Federated Learning: StackOverflow for next-word prediction and EMNIST for character recognition.

As part of our approach to partial personalization, we consider three partitioning schemes:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Input layer personalization: This architectural design focuses on customizing the input layer to learn personalized representations, while the remaining parts of the model are shared among all clients. Specifically, in the case of predicting the next word, we personalize the initial transformer layer instead of the embedding layer.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Output layer personalization: With this design, we aim to learn a shared representation while customizing the prediction layer. In the case of a transformer model, we adapt the final transformer layer instead of the output layer to achieve personalization.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Adapter personalization: In this scheme, each client utilizes a personalized low-rank adapter to fine-tune the global model.

These partitioning schemes serve as strategies for incorporating partial personalization into Federated Learning, allowing for different levels of customization while leveraging a shared model across clients.

E.2.1 StackOverflow for next word prediction

Dataset.

The dataset used for our task is derived from Stack Overflow, a popular programming question-answer website. It consists of questions and corresponding answers. In the next word prediction task, the objective is to forecast the subsequent word based on a partial sequence of words within a question or answer. This particular task serves as a valuable open-source benchmark for evaluating next-word prediction capabilities in mobile keyboards. For our experiments, we utilize the StackOverflow dataset made available by TensorFlow Federated222https://www.tensorflow.org/federated.

Client distributions.

Each client in our study corresponds to an individual user on Stack Overflow, and the data available to each client comprises the questions and answers posted by that specific user. To ensure an adequate amount of data for analysis, we only include clients with a minimum of 100100100 training sequences and 101010 testing sequences. Here, a sequence refers to either a question or an answer posted by the user. We further narrow down the dataset by utilizing a fixed subsample of 100010001000 clients.

Consistent with the approach described in Reddi et al. [48], we limit the vocabulary to the top 100001000010000 most frequently occurring words in the dataset. Additionally, we apply padding and truncation techniques to standardize the length of each sequence within each client, setting it to 202020. Furthermore, we consider a maximum of 100010001000 training sequences per client during our analysis.

Model.

For our implementation, we employ a transformer model [55] that is similar in size to BERT Mini [54]. The model consists of 444 transformer blocks, and each self-attention layer is equipped with 444 attention heads. The transformer hidden dimension is set to 256256256, while the fully-connected hidden dimension is 102410241024.

The model incorporates a causal language modeling head, which refers to a fully connected layer responsible for assigning scores to all possible vocabulary items, including special tokens.

Loss function and evaluation metric.

During the training phase, we utilize the causal language modeling objective. This means that for each partial sequence, we treat the task of predicting the next word as a multiclass classification problem and aim to minimize the cross-entropy loss.

For evaluation purposes, we employ the top-111 accuracy metric, which measures the accuracy of predicting the correct word from the proper 100001000010000-word vocabulary. This evaluation metric disregards special tokens such as padding, out-of-vocabulary terms, and beginning/end of sequence markers.

E.2.2 GLDv2 for Visual Landmark Recognition

Dataset.

Google Landmarks Dataset v2 (GLDv2)¬†[57] is a large-scale image dataset. This dataset comprises pictures of well-known landmarks across the globe, all of which were captured and uploaded by contributors to Wikipedia. Although the image dimensions vary, the most prevalent size is 800800800 by 600600600 pixels.

The primary objective of the visual landmark recognition assignment is to pinpoint the landmark depicted in the image. This task mirrors real-life situations where individuals use their smartphones to take pictures of natural or architectural landmarks during their travels. We utilize the federated version of the GLDv2 dataset by [19], which includes 2028 landmarks and is provided by TensorFlow Federated.

Client distributions.

Every client is associated with a specific Wikipedia user and includes all images contributed by that user. We only incorporate the 823 clients that have a minimum of 50 datapoints. We don‚Äôt utilize the original test set from GLDv2 for evaluation, as it originates from distinct clients. Rather, we allocate 50% of the data from each client to be used as a test set.

Model.

We employ a ResNet-18¬†[18] model, which has been pretrained on the ImageNet dataset¬†[11]. We use group normalization in place of batch normalization. All images are resized to dimensions of 224224224 by 224224224 pixels. Our training incorporates two data augmentations: a random cropping to a 256256256 by 256256256 size and a random horizontal flip.

Loss function and evaluation metric.

We use the cross-entropy loss. The model‚Äôs effectiveness is evaluated based on its classification accuracy.

E.2.3 EMNIST for Character Recognition

Dataset.

The EMNIST dataset [9] serves as a character recognition dataset. The objective is to identify images containing handwritten digits or letters, with a total of 62 possible options encompassing lowercase and uppercase letters (a-z, A-Z) as well as digits (0-9).

The images within the dataset are grayscale and have dimensions of 28√ó28282828\times 28, resulting in a total of 784 pixels. For our experiments, we utilize the EMNIST dataset made available by TensorFlow Federated.

Client Distributions.

In our study, each client represents an individual "writer," referring to the human subject who contributed by hand-writing the digit or letter during the data collection phase. We specifically consider clients that have a minimum of 100100100 training points and 252525 testing points, resulting in a total of 111411141114 eligible clients for analysis.

Model.

To address the smaller image size (28√ó28√ó12828128\times 28\times 1) in our dataset, which differs from the 224√ó224√ó32242243224\times 224\times 3 size that the original ResNet was designed for, we utilize a ResNet-18 model [18]. However, we make two modifications to accommodate this smaller size.

Firstly, we adjust the convolutional kernel size in the first convolution layer from the original 7√ó7777\times 7 to 3√ó3333\times 3. This modification allows the model to process the input images appropriately.

Secondly, we omit the first pooling layer that is present in the original ResNet architecture. By removing this layer, we ensure compatibility with our image size and maintain the effectiveness of the model for our specific task.

Loss function and evaluation metric.

We use the cross-entropy loss. We evaluate the performance of the model using its classification accuracy.

E.3 Experimental pipeline and baselines

There are three components in the training pipeline for all experiments:

  1. 1.

    Non-personalized federated pre-training: The first step involves training a global model without any personalization using FedAvg that we use to initialize (1).

  2. 2.

    Partially personalized federated training: This is the main training step that we describe in detail in Section¬†3.3.

  3. 3.

    Final finetuning: The last step involves only finetuning the personalized parameter wm‚àó‚Äã(Œ∏)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëöùúÉw_{m}^{*}(\theta) for each client.

E.4 Hyperparameters and evaluation Details

The hyperparameters we use are given in Table¬†2.

Evaluation metric.

Our main evaluation metric for both next-word prediction and image classification tasks is the weighted average of test accuracy across all clients. This weighted average takes into account the number of test examples from each client, allowing for a comprehensive assessment of model performance. This evaluation metric is equivalent to an unweighted accuracy achieved by aggregating all the data centrally.

Rounds.

We utilize the concept of communication rounds, which refers to the number of iterations during which the shared parameters are securely aggregated, to track the progress of each algorithm. In the case of non-personalized training, we set the number of rounds to 100010001000 for StackOverflow, 200020002000 for EMNIST, and 250025002500 rounds for GLDv2.

For personalized training, we initialize the model with the parameters obtained from the non-personalized training and continue training for an additional 500500500 rounds for both StackOverflow and EMNIST datasets, and 600600600 rounds for GLDv2.

Devices per round.

We assume that all devices are accessible and selections are made in a uniformly random manner. Consistent with the approach described in Reddi et al. [48], we choose 505050 devices per round for StackOverflow/GLDv2 and 101010 devices per round for EMNIST. This selection process applies to both non-personalized and personalized training for all datasets.

Local updates and minibatch size.

In both non-personalized and personalized federated training, each selected device executes one epoch of mini-batch stochastic gradient descent locally. Following this, during the final fine-tuning stage of personalized training, we perform five epochs of training.

For the StackOverflow and GLDv2 dataset, we utilize a mini-batch size of 64 across all settings. As for the EMNIST dataset, the mini-batch size is set to 32 for all configurations.

Server and client optimizer details.

For the EMNIST dataset, we utilize the FedAvg algorithm, while for the StackOverflow dataset and GLDv2, we employ FedAdam [48]. Additionally, we incorporate a global scheduler that applies a schedule to the client learning rates across multiple rounds, while maintaining a constant learning rate for each client within a round.

There are two types of schedulers we use: a linear scheduler and an exponential scheduler (referred to as "stepLR" in PyTorch). The linear scheduler involves a linear warmup, if applicable, until reaching the maximum learning rate, followed by a linear decay to 0. On the other hand, the exponential scheduler reduces the client learning rate by half after a fixed number of rounds.
